Fields.DialogueText: That last battle was a close call, wasn't it?
Ja, Kapitän, but using Admiral Reinhard Scheer's ingenious tactics from the Battle of Skagerrak allowed us to triumph over the Nixen and cause them serious losses!
We almost got our T crossed three times there, but those 180 degree turns really saved the day.
Ja, the Gefechtskehrtwendung nach Steuerbord, Kapitän! The "battle about turn" is an emergency maneuver that is never planned, but must be executed perfectly when the need arises.

Fields.MenuText: Never let it be said that drilling the crew doesn't pay off.
The sailors hated all the emergency drills you forced on them in the middle of the night, but they sure are thankful now.
Who would have thought that running away three times in a row would put us in a position to win?

Fields.DialogueText: There is a method behind my strict discipline, Kapitän. I am glad you recognize this.
An officer must prioritize the larger strategy and needs of the mission above the comfort of the sailors, Kapitän.
The Gefechtskehrtwendung is a tactical battle about turn, Kapitän. It is not a retreat!
Now that we've put a dent in the Morgana fleet, we need to plan our next mission.
We must solve our Torpedoblindgängernproblem, Kapitän.
You're still firing dud torpedos, Scheer?
It's not my problem alone, Kapitän! Kapitäne across the Kriegsmarine have been reporting Blindgänger ever since the war began.
So the entire Kriegsmarine lacks potent torpedos? I can see how this would be a problem. How can we fix it?
I will write Frau Marianne Besserer and small talk her for assistance, Kapitän. She is the daughter of the late Admiral Reinhard Scheer. Perhaps he passed some of his Torpedo expertise to her.
Seems like a strange thing to pass along to your child, but I suppose it wouldn't hurt to write her and ask if she has any suggestions.
*ALARM*
We'll have to take out these Morganas ahead of us before you can write that letter, Scheer. No retreating this time!
The Kriegsmarine is incapable of retreat, Kapitän! We merely Gefechtskehrtwendung for a more tactically advantageous position!
Call it whatever you want, Scheer - as long as we sink those Morganas!
@BATTLE
I know you regularly write Frau Besserer with your efficiency and after action reports, but what exactly will you ask her about the torpedos?
We need help solving the dud Torpedo problem, Kapitän. I have several theories as to the source of the malfunctions, but I wish to consult Frau Besserer before starting any trials.
What are your theories?
Der Torpedoblindgängern are widespread in the fleet. Reports of firing three or four Torpedos at the enemy without reliable detonation are commonplace.
My theories for the Blindgängern involve two issues - faulty detonators and inaccurate depth finding. The Kriegsmarine has been slow to respond, so I must conduct my own trials to solve the problem.

Fields.MenuText: That's very proactive of you, Scheer. You're really thinking about how to strengthen the entire fleet.
Do you really think this is something you can figure out on your own?
Shouldn't you wait until headquarters fixes the problem?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not out of my depth on this, Kapitän! I have studied the entire curriculum from Torpedo Research Command, and have practical experience Torpedoing enemies in a variety of positions!
A Kapitän focuses on the ship they command, but an Admiral must consider the fleet as a whole.
I'm not subverting the chain of command, Kapitän. But it is my duty to do everything within my means to ensure the destruction of our enemies.
Well, it seems like you're a good person to have heading up the investigation, Scheer. I'm sure Frau Besserer can help too.
Ja, Kapitän! I hope Frau Besserer recognizes my desire to take initiative as well. Whenever she is pleased with my performance, she sends me a tin of Scho-Ka-Kola!
So you're solving this torpedo crisis just so Frau Besserer will send you a tin of chocolate?
That is not the only reason, Kapitän! Have you ever tried Scho-Ka-Kola? If you eat enough of it, the caffeine enables you to work much harder and longer!
I suppose we should get Scho-Ka-Kola for the whole crew then?
One can only get treats if the performance was above standard, Kapitän. That is what Frau Bresserer tells me.
*ALARM*
We've got Morganas to deal with, Scheer! If you sink them fast enough, I'll ask the cooks to make some Welf pudding!
I am motivated by efficiency, not sweets, Kapitän! However, the destruction of the Nixen will be swift as usual!
@BATTLE
Oh, there you are, Scheer! I wanted to let you know that your letter to Frau Besserer went out with the last batch of mail.
Excellent, Kapitän. I will wait for her response. Until then, I will focus on other areas of need on the ship.
That's good to hear. I know you're always on top of things, Scheer. What else do we need to improve on?
Many things, Kapitän. The food in the mess, the amount of idle time the sailors have, the state of the other weapons on board - the list is long, and requires prioritization before taking action.

Fields.MenuText: What's wrong with the food in the mess?
The sailors hardly have any idle time as things stand now.
There are problems with the other weapons on the ship? Are we firing more duds?

Fields.DialogueText: Recent advancements in technology have made it possible to replace all the food in the mess with a fortified nutrient paste. This could greatly simplify our logistics process!
Die Mannschaft shouldn't have any idle time at all! Idle hands start mutinies, Kapitän - that is common knowledge!
No more Blindgänger, Kapitän, but the maintenance of the Kanonen should be made more frequent. There's nothing more unsightly than a schmutzige Kanone!
I thought you were starting to relax a bit, Scheer, but I'll let the crew know that "the Belle in the Iron Mask" is cracking down on things again.
I am not cracking down, Kapitän! I am fixing up! If no one enforces discipline on this ship, the readiness of die Mannschaft will go kaput!
I've been enforcing discipline well enough since we first weighed anchor. I think we should be okay.
The sailors have been smiling a lot since our last big battle, Kapitän. It makes me suspect that some sort of mutiny is being planned.
I think they're smiling because we've been fighting so well, and we're confident that we'll beat these Morganas soon enough.
That is an interesting theory that directly contradicts my suspicions, Kapitän. I suppose only one of us can be correct.
*GUNFIRE*
Morganas ahead, Scheer. Let's take care of the enemy first, then round up all these smiling mutineers later.
Jawohl, Kapitän! I'm glad you're finally seeing things my way!
@BATTLE
A response from Frau Besserer came in with the last batch of mail, Scheer.
Splendid, Kapitän! I will open it immediately. Oh, how I do love to receive letters from Frau Besserer...
I wonder if you earned any Scho-Ka-Kola this time...
Nein, Kapitän... but it seems she has responded to my inquiry about the Torpedos.
That's great! Did she have any ideas about what might be causing the duds?
"This is an important problem that demands immediate attention. I will analyze the situation and reply when I have devised a proper course of action."

Fields.MenuText: Wow, it seems like Frau Besserer is really up to the task!
She sounds just like her father. It's a little... scary.
Can we trust her? She's Admiral Reinhard Sheer's daughter, but that doesn't make her a torpedo expert.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course she is up to the task, Kapitän. She is the daughter of my namesake, after all.
I'm glad my namesake taught his daughter how to think critically. I'm sure he must have taught her a thing or two about Torpedo design...
Is there anything in her response that indicates a lack of expertise in the field of Torpedos? Nein, Kapitän. She is a Scheer, and Scheers know their Torpedos!
Well, I'm glad you'll get some help on this. With both you and Frau Besserer working together, I'm sure you'll solve the dud torpedo problem soon enough!
Natürlich, Kapitän. Oh, if only her father was still around to see us at work...
Are you getting a little sentimental there, Scheer?
... Nein, Kapitän! I was only thinking about how Admiral Scheer might help us solve our Blindgängerproblem with even greater efficiency. We must destroy the Nixen without further delay!
*ALARM*
Well, you can start your destruction with these Morganas ahead of us, Scheer.
Jawohl, Kapitän! Commence firing!
@BATTLE
Are you really thinking about replacing all the fresh food in the mess with canned nutrient paste from a factory?
My calculations show that it will result in a dramatic savings of time, weight, and storage space, Kapitän. The numbers speak for themselves.
Remember that Labskaus you ate? It brought back happy memories of Reinhard Scheer's cadet school days, and it really boosted your morale!
Ja, Kapitän. However, the calculated logistics savings of the canned nutrient paste outweigh any measureable morale benefit from serving gourmet food on a warship.

Fields.MenuText: Labskaus is hardly gourmet food...
Nutrient paste? Are you going out of your way to convince the crew to mutiny?
Food that reminds the sailors of home will only make them miss it even more. Canned food will help them focus on work!

Fields.DialogueText: You have never tasted properly prepared Labskaus, Kapitän! Oh, that savory smell and the way it fills one's Magen...
Mutiny? Have you heard anything through your small talk with die Mannshaft? My informants have reported nothing of late.
Ja, Kapitän! I'm glad you understand how distracting good food on a warship can be!
Well, I wouldn't advise any sudden changes in the mess. The crew can be pretty temperamental about their food sometimes.
Ja, Kapitän. In any case, I suppose we must exhaust our current supply of fresh food before restocking the kitchen with canned nutrient paste.
*ALARM*
Sorry to interrupt your inspection of the mess, Scheer, but we've got some Morganas to sink.
Combat is a welcome interruption to watching die Mannshaft sitting here chewing their food, Kapitän.
We would save a lot of time if the crew didn't chew their food so much...
The nutrient paste has many quantifiable advantages, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
That said, I wouldn't advise any sudden changes in the mess. The crew can be pretty temperamental about their food sometimes.
Here's a response from Frau Besserer, Scheer.
Ah, she wrote back! Thank you you for the letter, Kapitän.
What does Frau Besserer have to say about the dud torpedo problem?
This is very interesting, Kapitän... and her theory appears to be in line with my suspicions. She suspects faulty detonators.

Fields.MenuText: Of course! The detonators are an obvious culprit for a dud problem.
Detonators? That doesn't sound likely to me...
What isn't in line with your suspicions, Scheer?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän. We have no problem launching the Torpedos and reaching the target, but detonation frequently eludes us. The detonator mechanism itself is the likely point of failure.
Kapitän, it doesn't take a Torpedomeister to suspect that faulty detonators might be the source of our Blindgängerproblem.
My suspicions always have a high degree of accuracy, Kapitän. Nonetheless, I prefer to crosscheck my suspicions with other experts or informants when they are available.
Faulty detonators are an obvious cause, but Frau Besserer does go on with detailed technical theories for the failures...
Ah, that's interesting! What are her theories?
The details of her theories are streng geheim, Kapitän. I'm afraid I cannot share classified information with you.
I'm the ship's captain, Scheer. Of course you can tell me!
That is simply not true, Kapitän. In fact, I shouldn't have even mentioned the Blindgängerproblem to you at all - it's a matter for only the highest levels of the Kriegsmarine.
Oh come on! Everyone on the ship knows you're firing duds, Scheer!
Please. Kapitän! Not so loudly when die Mannschaft is present!
*ALARM*
Morganas ahead! Hit them with everything we've got - except for the duds of course!
No need to shout, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
It's not a secret that we've got a dud torpedo problem, Scheer.
Thanks to you shouting about die Blindgänger in front of all the spies and conspirators on die Schiffsbrücke, Kapitän!
There are no spies and conspirators on the bridge, Scheer. They're the crew, and we're all in this war together.
You have compromised die streng geheimen Informationen, Kapitän. What is your plan to contain this breach?

Fields.MenuText: You're really overreacting, Scheer. We've fired countless duds, and the whole crew can see that there's a problem.
We're on a ship at sea. None of these sailors are going anywhere anytime soon.
You're not putting me on trial here, Scheer. It's up to the Kriegsmarine to decide if I've done anything wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: Is it really that obvious? I suppose any of the spies or conspirators on board would have picked up on our unreliable detonation by now...
Excellent point, Kapitän. We will screen all outgoing communications to ensure there are no futher leaks, and thoroughly small talk die Mannschaft before they disembark.
Don't bring up technicalities with me, Kapitän. We both know what you've done!
The whole crew already knows about the duds, Scheer. The most productive thing we can do is work together to solve the problem.
I suppose you're right, Kapitän. That does seem to be the most efficient course of action given the circumstances. The Blindgänger are affecting the whole Kriegsmarine, after all.
Right. So you don't have to tell me the details about the detonators, but let me know how we can help.
Yes... well.. in a general sense, the detonators may have a problem... relating to... certain parts...
I would like your assistance in conducting a series of trials to fire Torpedos, identify design problems, and test potential solutions.
That sounds perfectly reasonable, Scheer. We can get started immediately.
*BOOM*
Well, immediately after we take care of these Morganas. Return fire!
@BATTLE
So what are we testing with this torpedo launch, Scheer? Is this to figure out what's wrong with the faulty detonators?
No need to speak so loudly when die Mannschaft is present, Kapitän!
I'm speaking in a normal tone of voice... and there's no one around anyway.
No one that you can see, Kapitän, but the bulkheads have ears, as they say!
Does anyone actually say that? I've heard "the walls have ears," but--
Ach! According to the clock, the Torpedos should have detonated by now, but the wrecked ship we're using as a target is still floating out there. The detonators failed again.
Well, that shouldn't be too surprising...
Ja, Kapitän. However, as you can see, the Torpedos we launched have wires running into this box. The box collected data that I will send to Frau Besserer for further analysis.

Fields.MenuText: That's great! I'm sure Frau Besserer can take a look at the data and identify what's wrong with the detonators.
How is that box collecting data? What kind of new technology is that?
Can she really figure out what's wrong with the detonators just by looking at data?

Fields.DialogueText: That is what I am hoping for, Kapitän. Frau Besserer does seem to have a keen eye for analysis, especially when it comes to Torpedos.
Streng geheimen Informationen, Kapitän. The Kriegsmarine has made several technological advances in recent months, but I can't talk about any details.
Data is the only way we can figure anything out, Kapitän. A decision made without data is merely conjecture.
Well, at least this data will help us get one step closer to solving the dud torpedo problem.
*BOOM*
It seems that the wrecked ship we were using as a target is now firing at us, Kapitän.
That's because it's not a wrecked ship after all - it's a Morgana! Return fire, Scheer!
@BATTLE
Is that the letter you're sending to Frau Besserer, Scheer?
Ja, Kapitän. I have written her to explain the results of our last detonator trial.
That's great! What's in that package along with the letter?
It is the data recorded from the Torpedos, Kapitän. It is streng geheimen Informationen, of course.

Fields.MenuText: We'll make sure the data is transported safely and securely, Scheer.
I'm curious... can you show me what's inside?
You shouldn't have that package out in the open where everyone can see it...

Fields.DialogueText: Vielen Dank, Kapitän. I trust you will send the package immediately.
Of course not, Kapitän. I have already given you enough information to support his operation - perhaps too much information, actually...
Conspirators and spies are inevitable amongst die Mannschaft. If we follow proper security protocols, the data will not be compromised, Kapitän.
We'll send your package with the next mail shipment, Scheer. Just hand off everything to Obermaat Baumann, and he'll take care of it.
Obermaat Baumann? I small talked him earlier about the ship's optimal cruising speed. He was unable to answer, Kapitän. He is either incompetent or untrustworthy!
Obermaat Baumann is in charge of the mail, and we haven't had any complaints regarding both official correspondence and personal mail. I'm sure everything will be fine.
An incompetent sailor serving in a trusted position handling classified communications? He's clearly a target for any enemy intelligence operation!
You're jumping to a lot of conclusions here, Scheer...
Die Mannschaft cannot be trusted, Kapitän! The conspirators on board are only one smoke break away from mutiny!
*GUNFIRE*
You're sounding a little paranoid! We can talk more after we take care of these Morganas. I'm not sure what's gotten into you lately, Scheer!
Nichts ist in mich gefahren! Nothing has gotten into me lately, Kapitän! These Torpedoblindgängern are making me very frustrated!
Well, you can blow off some steam by blowing these Morganas out of the water!
@BATTLE
We've already got a response from Frau Besserer, Scheer. I wanted you to open the letter here in my quarters to make sure no one else hears the conversation.
Ach! No doubt Obermaat Baumann and the rest of his conspirators have already read the contents.
You've got absolutely no evidence that Obermaat Baumann or anyone else on this ship is plotting against you, Scheer.
Why would spies leave evidence, Kapitän? Deine naivität is quite disappointing! The first rule of espionage is to avoid getting caught at all costs.

Fields.MenuText: Your levels of paranoia truly are impressive, Scheer!
I'm not familiar with all the rules of espionage, Scheer. I'm a ship's captain, not a spy.
Maybe we should small talk Obermaat Baumann to figure out who he's spying for...

Fields.DialogueText: I assure you my suspicions are perfectly logical, Kapitän! My namesake dealt with widespread mutiny during der Kieler Matrosenaufstand. Sailors must never be trusted!
I admit there are no official rules of espionage from the Oberkommando - although I am working on a draft Manuskript on the matter in my spare time...
Excellent idea, Kapitän! He didn't answer my small talk the first time, but perhaps that was a counterintelligence tactic on his part. Perhaps he's more clever than I assumed...
In any case, what does Frau Besserer's letter say?
Hmm... die Magnete! Logisch!
The dud torpedo problem is caused by a problem with the magnetic detonators?
Why must you always speak so loudly, Kapitän?
*BOOM*
Sounds like we're taking fire from Morganas again! We need to get to the bridge.
Jawohl, Kapitän! Werde ich Nixen vernichten!
@BATTLE
So what's your plan for the next torpedo trial? Frau Besserer thinks the duds are caused by a problem with the magnetic detonators, right?
You have quite the annoying habit of explaining the obvious out loud, Kapitän! There are potential saboteurs and spies out here on the deck.
My apologies, Scheer, but clear communication is essential on a ship. In fact, that's why commands are always verbally acknowledged on a ship - everyone has to be on the same page--
We must not be on the same page as die Mannschaft, Kapitän - we must be several chapters ahead! How many times must I warn you about the risk die Mannschaft poses to the success of our mission?

Fields.MenuText: Most navies think the crew is critical to mission success, not a threat to it, Scheer.
So you plan to accomplish our mission without the help of the crew?
You're right, Scheer! We must keep the crew under control at all times.

Fields.DialogueText: Die Mannschaft is the most delicate component on a ship, Kapitän. When the ship is stressed, die Mannschaft is always the first part to break.
Of course we need die Mannschaft, Kapitän - just as we need fuel and ammunition... but they are the only resource on the ship capable of mutiny.
This is why I've been eliminating any free time for the sailors, Kapitän. Now you see the logic of my longer shifts!
You really *are* the Belle with the Iron Mask! I thought you were taking steps to get to know the sailors a little better...
I'm not here to make friends, Kapitän. My sole objective is to destroy the Nixen. Die Mannschaft is merely a tool to accomplish the mission.
Well, we'll definitely need the crew's support to solve this torpedo problem and win the war against the Morganas. We need to treat the crew well to make sure they're on our side.
This is the Kriegsmarine, Kapitän. There are more important priorities than treating sailors well.
*GUNFIRE*
Morganas ahead! We can debate our priorities later, Scheer!
Debate is so inefficient, Kapitän! The destruction of the Nixen ist von größter Bedeutung!
@BATTLE
There are many eyes around us, Kapitän. It seems there are more sailors than usual out here on the deck.
Yes, I suppose word got out that we're about to run your latest torpedo trial to test the improved magnetic detonator design that Frau Besserer sent you.
Mein Gott, Herr Kapitän! The security on this ship has more holes than schweizer Käse! How can you tolerate such an open breach of streng geheimen Informationen?

Fields.MenuText: The crew had to fit the experimental detonators onto the torpedos - there was no way to hide the truth from them.
The whole crew wants to help fix this torpedo problem. Everyone's tired of firing duds in the heat of battle!
We must round up all the witnesses and question them until they break!

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose this is true, Kapitän. It's so inefficient to rely on human hands to do so much...
It only takes one Klatschmaul on die Mannschaft to expose our secrets to the enemy, Kapitän!
There will be a lot of small talk to do with die Mannschaft after this Torpedo trial, Kapitän!
In any case, the torpedos are all ready to go with the new magnetic detonators. We might as well get the trial started and fire them at the test target out there.
Ja, Kapitän. We can deal with all the witnesses later. Torpedos abfeuern!
The torpedoes are in the water... they're heading towards the test target...
Jippi! Oh, it makes me so excited to see Torpedos armed and ready to explodieren!
If those new magnetic detonator designs work, the torpedoes should be hitting the test target right about now...
*BOOM*
Hurra, Kapitän! The new detonator designs worked! I knew we could depend on Frau Besserer's expertise!
Yes, Scheer! Look, all the sailors on deck are cheering too! We did it!
The crew is much like the ship's Kapitän in its lack of subtlety. I'm sure any Nixen ships watching know the test was a success as well.
It doesn't matter who knows what we're up to now, Scheer! We fixed the torpedo problem!
*GUNFIRE*
Are you testing the guns too, Scheer?
Nein, Kapitän! The Nixen approach! Gefechtsstationen!
@BATTLE
On further inspection, it seems that only one of the four torpedoes from the last trial actually detonated on target. The other three were duds.
Ja, Kapitän... this Blindgängerproblem continues to frustrate me!
We are making progress though! One of the torpedoes exploded on target, but maybe the detonator isn't the only source of the problem.
Perhaps there is more than one design flaw in our Torpedos, Kapitän...

Fields.MenuText: Torpedos are complex. There are many different parts that could be causing the dud problem.
Maybe Frau Besserer can tell us what she thinks?
It's possible, but would the Kriegsmarine really deploy a weapon with so many flaws?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän, We must continue to investigate all possibilities.
She was right about the magnetic detonators, but perhaps there are additional faults in the design...
Probieren geht über studieren! The proof is in the pudding, Kapitän!
I'm sure Frau Besserer will have more ideas to solve the problem. Did you record the data from the torpedoes again?
Ja, Kapitän. All of the data for Frau Besserer is here in this package. It is all streng geheimen Informationen, of course.
Great! Just hand everything over to Obermaat Baumann over there, and he'll make sure the package goes out with the next mail shipment.
Ach! Obermaat Baumann! You were standing at the door spying on us this whole time? What did you hear, Obermaat Baumann? Tell me at once!
Nichts, Frau Schiffsdame!
Nichts?! I find that very hard to believe!
*ALARM*
Quite good timing to plan all this right before an attack by the Nixen! I must applaud the exceptional coordination of your espionage, Obermaat Baumann!
Obermaat Baumann is just doing his job, Scheer. Please hand him the package, and let's get to the bridge to deal with these Morganas. It's all standard procedure.
The standard procedure on this ship seems to leak more secrets than an Abwehr informant, Kapitän!
No time for debate, Scheer! We've got Morganas to deal with first!
@BATTLE
Thank you for finally handing that package over to Obermaat Baumann, Scheer. You've been really on edge with this torpedo crisis, but you need to learn to trust the crew.
I suppose you're right, Kapitän. Not all of die Mannschaft can be mutineers or spies - at least statistically, it's not very likely.
Right. The sailors just want to win the war quickly so we can all go home. They all want to help solve the dud torpedo problem so we can sink more Morganas.
Do they really want to win the war quickly, Kapitän? It seems they waste a tremendous amount of time sleeping, smoking, playing cards, and writing letters to their families.

Fields.MenuText: Life on a warship is weeks of boredom interrupted by moments of pure terror. The sailors need a little time for themselves!
I admit we could work the crew a little harder, but I think it would hurt their morale.
Smoking and gambling are signs of moral weakness. We should ban both activities on board!

Fields.DialogueText: Any time to themselves will undoubtedly result in thoughts of mutiny, Kapitän. It's a predictable human response to the situation.
An efficient ship is run just on the brink of mutiny, Kapitän. If we want the most out of die Mannschaft, we must bend them to our will without breaking them.
Ja, Kapitän! The smoking causes health problems, and the gambling leads to fights amongst the sailors. There is no benefit to any of this!
I still think it would be helpful for you to be a little more approachable. Most of the sailors are still afraid of you, and I think it prevents us from working efficiently.
How can we maintain order and motivate the crew to do anything without making them fear us, Kapitän?
Fear isn't the only way to motivate sailors, Scheer!
Ha, that's a good one, Kapitän! Call me old fashioned, but if you can figure out a way to motivate die Mannschaft without using fear, ich bin ganz Ohr! I am all ears, as they say!
I wasn't joking, Scheer! I was being seri--
*BOOM*
Ja! Nothing like incoming fire to motivate the crew, Kapitän! Gefechtsstationen, everyone!
@BATTLE
Here's the latest letter from Frau Besserer, Scheer.
Danke schön, Kapitän. Let's see what she has to say about the Torpedo data I sent her...
Just so you're aware before you start reading, the door to my quarters is closed, and there are no sailors within earshot.
I'm pleased that you're finally paying attention to such basic matters of security, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just mentioning it to help calm you down, Scheer. It's an appeasement strategy.

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr aufmerksam - but appeasement usually doesn't work in the long run, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: It's just standard security procedure.
We must be careful - there's no telling how many spies are on this ship!

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! If you cared to follow standard security procedures from the start, my embarrassing Blindgängerproblem wouldn't be such common knowledge!
Ja, Kapitän! I've become particularly suspicious of Obermaat Baumann lately. I can't prove it, but I'm certain he's reading all of the correspondence with Frau Besserer.
That's good to know for future reference. In any case, what has Frau Besserer written this time?
"Excellent work with the new magnetic detonator design... but unfortunate to hear there are more problems... "
So I'm guessing she didn't send any Scho-Ka-Kola this time?
Nein, Kapitän... "I have analyzed the latest data you sent, and have concluded there is another fault with the Torpedo design..."
I knew it! So there is more than one problem causing the dud torpedoes!
Again, Kapitän, there is no need to repeat these things in such a loud voice!
*ALARM*
The door is closed, Scheer, so I'm sure Obermaat Baumann can't hear anything on the other side.
He's waiting outside?! Why didn't you tell me that? I'm sure he was listening to every word we were saying!
I told Obermaat Baumann to stand by outside in case you wrote a quick response to send back to Frau Besserer.
Ach! Your casual attitude towards security is extremely frustrating, Kapitän! Enough small talk for now - let's destroy these Nixen!
@BATTLE
So Frau Besserer thinks there's also a problem with the depth keeping system on the torpedoes?
Ja, Kapitän. The data seems to indicate this is an additional point of failure for the Blindgängerproblem.
Hmm... that does fit with what we're seeing. The torpedoes are on target, but if they're running too deep, they'll pass right under the target instead of detonating.
Correct, Kapitän. In this trial, we will focus data collection on the depth finding mechanism. There seem to be fewer witnesses on the deck this time. Perhaps the spies are unaware of our trial.

Fields.MenuText: We'll fire four more torpedos at that test target out there, and see how many detonate.
For the last time, Scheer, there are no spies on the ship!
The spies must have gotten bored of watching you fire so many duds.

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän, and we'll monitor their depth more closely this time. We'll never get reliable detonation if we go in too deep!
The second rule of espionage is to make the enemy believe you're on their side, Kapitän.
I admit that watching the Blindgänger fail to detonate is hardly exciting, but I'm here to solve a Torpedokrise, not put on a show for voyeuristic saboteurs!
I suppose you're right, Scheer.
Let's get this trial started, Kapitän. I have attached the wires from the Torpedos to the data collection box, and the test target is straight ahead.
Okay, we're all set! Launch the torpedoes!
Oh, there they go, Kapitän! It's always so exciting to watch Torpedos slowly approaching their target!
Scheer, there's a sailor with binoculars standing by the railing. He's watching the torpedos too... but he's too far away and I can't see his face...
Ich glaub mich knutscht ein Elch! It must be Obermaat Baumann! I knew he was a spy for the Nixen!
*BOOM*
Incoming fire from Morganas, Scheer! We need to get to our battle stations right away!
Ach! Where did that sailor run off to? We must track down that spy, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
I'm certain that spy with the binoculars was Obermaat Baumann, Kapitän!
Even if it was Obermaat Baumann, it's not out of the ordinary for sailors to keep watch with binoculars. It is one of their regular duties, after all.
Möglicherweise... but the timing was rather suspicious, don't you think?
You think everything is suspicious, Scheer. Now what did we learn from that last torpedo trial? Only two of the four torpedoes detonated properly.
It does appear to be a problem with the depth finding mechanism, Kapitän. The torpedos are running too deep on occasion.

Fields.MenuText: Time to write Frau Besserer again to see if she has any solutions.
With faulty detonators and incorrect depth finding, it's a miracle these torpedos are going off at all!
Can a torpedo really run too deep for you, Scheer?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän. She suspected the depth finding might be at fault, but did not suggest any solutions in her last letter. Perhaps the additional data from this trial will be helpful.
The Blindgängerproblem has certainly frustrated Kapitäne across the entire Kriegsmarine. They all desire reliable detonation, Kapitän!
Natürlich, Kapitän. What kind of question is that? If the Torpedo is too far underwater, the detonator will fail to detect the target, and - ein weiterer Torpedoblindgänger.
Well, once you've finished your letter for Frau Besserer, you can give the package to Obermaat Baumann as usual.
I would prefer it if another Maat handled the streng geheim correspondence with Frau Besserer from now on, Kapitän.
You really don't trust Obermaat Baumann, do you?
*ALARM*
The third rule of espionage is to trust no one, Kapitän!
That's fine, Scheer - but this is a warship, and the first rule of a warship is to work together to defeat the enemy! So get to your battle station and let's sink some Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
We'll have to wait until we get a response from Frau Besserer on the depth finding problem with the torpedoes. In the meantime, we can make sure the rest of the ship is running efficiently.
Ja, Kapitän. I must admit that I've been so frustrated with the Torpedokrise that I have been neglecting other areas in need of improvement.
In some ways, the crew has appreciated a little less oversight from you while you've been preoccupied with the torpedo problem, Scheer.
What do you mean, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: You haven't run any midnight Gefechtskehrtwendung drills with the crew lately.
The crew has enjoyed relaxing dinner hours without you yelling "Schnell! Schnell!" while they're eating.
The sailors have been sleeping more soundly since you're so preoccupied studying torpedo data at night.

Fields.DialogueText: Ach! You're right, Kapitän! Die Mannschaft becomes mehr und mehr undisciplined the longer this Torpedokrise continues!
Die Mannschaft takes an whole hour to eat their meals now? Is this how they act when I'm not watching? Perhaps I shouldn't spend my entire evening examining the Torpedos...
Ist das so? If die Mannschaft is too well-rested, they might have more energy for a mutiny, Kapitän!
We must solve the Torpedokrise quickly, Kapitän! It is impossible to effectively control die Mannschaft with my head stuck in a Torpedorohre all day...
Don't worry about controlling the crew, Scheer. Crew morale is really high right now thanks to everyone getting more sleep and longer breaks. You can concentrate on the torpedoes for now.
Are you saying that my leadership is no longer needed amongst die Mannschaft, Kapitän? If they no longer fear me, who is motivating them to carry out their daily duties?
I've got it under control, Scheer. Don't worry - the other officers and petty officers have really stepped up lately. It's been great to see everyone taking initiative on their own.
Mist! Is this a putsch, Kapitän? A coup d'état? Are you trying to oust me? Am I being overthrown?!
Calm down, Scheer! We're all working together. I just meant that it's okay for you to focus on the torpedos, because the rest of the crew can handle things in your absence.
My absence?! Am I being sent away, Kapitän? Exiled? Imprisoned?
*ALARM*
No one is sending you anywhere, Scheer! Now please get to your battle station - we've got Morganas incoming!
Jawohl, Herr Kapitän! Please remember - I have always been loyal to you, and faithful to the mission of the Kriegsmarine! No one can question my commitment to the cause!
@BATTLE
Obermaat Baumann just delivered this latest response from Frau Besserer.
Vielen Dank, Kapitän. This letter looks like it has been opened and resealed, but I wouldn't expect any less from Obermaat Baumann these days...
I suppose your paranoia is part of your charm, Scheer... in any case, does Frau Besserer have any ideas to fix the depth finding mechanism?
Hmm... ja... natürlich! She recommends increased maintenance of the torpedo chamber to ensure that the pressure sensor is properly calibrated.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that over time, changes in atmospheric pressure could cause incorrect readings in the depth sensor. Daily maintenance of the torpedos should fix the problem.
The crew does have more free time lately. It wouldn't hurt to schedule more time for torpedo maintenance.
You're inspecting the torpedoes every night anyway, so keeping the depth sensor calibrated won't be too much more work for you.

Fields.DialogueText: The problem is even worse for U-boats, Kapitän. The constant pressure changes of going auf und ab must be chaos for their Torpedos!
The crew shouldn't have any free time, Kapitän. Any gaps in their schedule should be devoted to cleaning die Kanonen and maintaining the Torpedos.
I suppose I could ask die Mannschaft to inspect the Torpedos, but it is an important task that deserves my... personal attention.
Okay, so if we follow Frau Besser's advice and make sure the depth sensors are regularly calibrated, we should launch a lot fewer duds.
Ja, Kapitän! We will run another trial tomorrow with freshly calibrated Torpedos! The thought of finally having functional Torpedos... excites me greatly!
I'm excited too, Scheer! We're finally on course to solve this torpedo problem!
*GUNFIRE*
It seems that die Kanoniere are excited as well, Kapitän! Let's clear out these Nixen to make room for our next trial!
@BATTLE
Okay, the depth finders in the torpedoes have just been serviced, and we're ready to launch at the test target.
Excellent, Kapitän! With the improved magnetic detonators and more accurate depth finding, I think we can say auf Wiedersehen to das Blindgängerproblem!

Fields.MenuText: Well, we'll have to run the trial first before we can declare a success.
With fully functional torpedoes, no Morgana out there will be safe from us!
I honestly can't wait for you to finally stop complaining about duds all the time!

Fields.DialogueText: We're certainly getting close to the climax of this Torpedokrise, Kapitän!
Ja, Kapitän. Man soll das Fell des Bären nicht verteilen, bevor man ihn erlegt hat. One shouldn’t divide up the bearskin before killing the bear!
We have been making do with die Kanonen, but die Torpedos are a far more elegant weapon of destruction, Kapitän!
Well, I suppose it's time to fire at the test target. Launch the torpedoes!
Kapitän, is that Obermaat Baumann over there by the railing with the binoculars again? That little voyeur is clearly spying on our Torpedos!
Can't you enjoy the moment, Scheer? The torpedos are about to hit the target, but you're all caught up in your elaborate conspiracy theories.
That IS Obermaat Baumann! I can make out his face this time. I will certainly small talk him later about his perverse espionage habits!
Scheer, the torpedoes should have hit by now... but nothing has happened...
Ach! All four of the Torpedos failed to detonate? What is the meaning of this?!
*ALARM*
No time to worry about the failed test now, Scheer. We've got Morganas approaching!
I am certain Obermaat Baumaan is behind this, Kapitän! He will not escape my small talk this time!
@BATTLE
I will write Frau Besserer immediately after we small talk with Obermaat Baumann, Kapitän.
I think Obermaat Baumann deserves a chance to explain his actions, but I did call him in here so you can speak with him.
Danke schön for appeasing me, Kapitän. The small talk will be swift and direct! Obermaat Baumann wird es ausspucken!

Fields.MenuText: That sounds a little harsh, Scheer! Why don't we just ask him nicely?
He has been acting strangely, but let's hear his side of the story.
... ausspucken?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann wird es ausspucken! Obermaat Baumann will spit out the truth!
Perhaps he has a good explanation for why he is reading top secret correspondence and conducting surveillance on our Torpedo trials. Ja, Kapitän!
"Hallo, Obermaat Baumann! Schönes Wetter heute, was? Why are you spying for die Nixen?" That never works, Kapitän!
*KNOCK*
*DOOR_OPEN*
Ah, Obermaat Baumann! Please come in.
*FOOTSTEPS*
I will cut straight to the small talk, Obermaat Baumann.
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame!
Have you been opening and reading my correspondence with Frau Besserer regarding the Torpedokrise, even though the letters are streng geheimen Informationen?
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame!
Heiliger Strohsack! You admit your crimes so readily? And have you been spying on our torpedo trials with your binoculars?
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame!
Well, I think we're done here, Kapitän! Obermaat Baumann should be confined to the Schiffsgefängnis immediately!
*BOOM*
Always such coincidental timing between incidents involving Obermaat Baumann and die Nixen attacking, Kapitän!
Obermaat Baumann, you'll have to explain yourself after we take care of these Morganas!
Jawohl, Herr Kapitän!
@BATTLE
We should give Obermaat Baumann a chance to explain himself before throwing him in the brig, Scheer.
Let's make it quick, Obermaat Baumann!
My last assignment was at Torpedo Research Command, Frau Schiffsdame! I want to solve the Torpedokrise more than anything!
Ist das so?
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame! I have experience with both detonator and depth finder design, so I was analyzing the letters and Torpdeo data to see if I could help come up with a solution.
I see.

Fields.MenuText: This all makes sense! You were trying to help all along!
It's great that you wanted to help, but that's no excuse for reading top secret correspondence.
Did you manage to come up with any solutions to the dud torpedo problem?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I was trying to help, Herr Kapitän! The whole crew has been working together to solve this Torpedokrise!
Ja, Herr Kapitän! I have no excuse for breaking the rules, but I assure you my intentions were only to help solve the Torpedokrise!
The analysis from Frau Besserer and the data recorded during the trials were all very helpful, Herr Kapitän!
There are certainly problems with the magnetic detonator and depth finder designs, but I also identified a third problem with the contact detonators!
Magnetic detonators can be unreliable due to inconsistent magnetic fields in the ocean. Contact detonators are an alternative physical trigger, but the design is overly complex and prone to failure.
However, using the data from the Torpedo trials and my experience at Torpedo Research Command, I designed a simpler and more reliable contact detonator that should solve our remaining problems!
That's brilliant! We'll test your new contact detonator design immediately!
Kapitän, on one hand, I want to confine Obermaat Baumann to the Schiffsgefängnis immediately, but on the other, hearing him talk about fixing the detonation problem makes me so... excited!
*GUNFIRE*
If Obermaat Baumann helps solve the torpedo crisis, we're definitely not sending him to the brig, Scheer! Now lets sink these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Okay, the torpedos have Obermaat Baumann's new contact detonators, along with the improved magnetic detonators and calibrated depth finders.
If we still have Torpedoblindgängern after all this, I'm not sure what else we can do, Kapitän.
I'm tired of firing duds too, Scheer. So let's hope that Obermaat Baumann's help was the final thing we needed.
It's strange relying on die Mannschaft to help solve problems for the entire Kriegsmarine. Perhaps I have underestimated the potential of individual sailors to contribute to the greater war effort.

Fields.MenuText: Individuals can always make a difference. Imagine if Admiral Reinhard Scheer wasn't commanding the fleet at Jutland.
Sailors aren't just another part on the ship. The crew can accomplish so much more than any piece of machinery.
If you work the crew hard enough, they can accomplish anything!

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Skagerrakschlacht would have been a total disaster without the Gefechtskehrtwendung of my namesake, Kapitän!
I wish they could accomplish things without so much sleeping, eating, gambling, complaining, and smoking, Kapitän!
If we really do solve the Torpedokrise with this new contact detonator, I can refocus my attention on monitoring die Mannschaft, Kapitän!
Let's hope this is the last trial! Launch the torpedoes!
Ah, seeing Torpedos slide into the water never fails to excite me, Kapitän! Let's see if they all detonate reliably this time...
The torpedoes should be on target right about now...
*BOOM*
Hurra! They're all direct hits, Kapitän! All four Torpedos detonated on target!
Ha! That's fantastic! We owe Obermaat Baumann a lot for solving the last piece of the puzzle!
I will write Frau Besserer immediately with the good news! The Kriegsmarine is a force to be reckoned with yet again!
*GUNFIRE*
Seems like the Morganas haven't heard the news yet, but let's give them all we've got!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Fighting Morganas is so much easier now that we've got reliable torpedos!
Ja, Kapitän! When one has a Blindgängernproblem with Torpedos, it becomes very predictable relying on die Kanonen to get the job done.
Although I suppose being predictable doesn't have much impact on how we fight the Morganas. It seems like they keep coming at us no matter what we do.
All the more reason to ensure all our weapons systems are functional, and that die Mannschaft is ready to respond to our commands.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for the hard work on this sortie, Scheer. I know we don't always agree, but your methods have achieved the results we needed.
I'm glad this torpedo crisis is behind us. What should we focus on next?
The crew doesn't always need to blindly follow our commands, Scheer. Sometimes they have good ideas to contribute too.

Fields.DialogueText: My primary focus remains the destruction of the Nixen, Kapitän. Everything must run as efficiently as possible to bring us a swift victory over our enemies.
That is a good question, Kapitän. As our overall goal is the destruction of the Nixen, our focus must be whatever objectives will bring us closer to that end.
You're really not going to stop mentioning this whole Obermaat Baumann incident, are you?
In any case, I'm glad we worked together to solve the torpedo crisis.
Yes, I suppose we do owe a bit of thanks to Obermaat Baumann as well...
Have you apologized to him yet for all your ridiculous accusations that he was spying for the Morganas?
Why would I apologize for that? Obermaat Baumann could be a double agent, after all. I'm still watching him very closely!
*GUNFIRE*
There's no other Belle quite like you, Scheer! Let's sink a few more Morganas!
Jawohl, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
You seem so much more relaxed now that we've fixed the dud torpedos, Scheer.
I must apologize, Kapitän. The Torpedokrise left me feeling very frustrated on most evenings. My temperment has slowly returned back to normal now that the Torpedos are detonating reliably.
Back to normal? So you're back to being "The Belle with the Iron Mask"?
That's what die Mannschaft prefers calling me. It's of no significance to me, Kapitän, as long as they continue following orders.
*KNOCK*
*DOOR_OPEN*
Ah, Obermaat Baumann! I wasn't expecting you!
I have a package from Frau Besserer, Herr Kapitän.
I'll take that, Obermaat Baumann. Danke schön.
Ja, Frau Schiffsdame!
What's in the package, Scheer?
"Thank you for solving the Torpedokrise..." It's... a tin of Scho-Ka-Kola from Frau Besserer, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: Well, eat up, Scheer! You deserve it!
Don't you think you should give that to Obermaat Baumaan?
Obermaat Baumann, please grab a seat so we can all share this chocolate!

Fields.DialogueText: Did I really deserve it, Kapitän? Hurra! I get such a warm feeling inside when Frau Besserer praises me!
I suppose... I can give him one wedge.
I suppose we can all celebrate our achievement together, Kapitän. But please don't get too comfortable, Obermaat Baumann - you're still on duty.
*ALARM*
Terrible timing for a Morgana attack! We can get back to this Scho-Ka-Kola later - battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Hey Scheer, where did the Scho-Ka-Kola go? We left it right here on the table...
This ship is full of saboteurs and spies, Kapitän! Now do you believe me?
Obermaat Baumann! Where are you - and what did you do with the Scho-Ka-Kola?
